Thanks to all for your very useful responses..  John, you are 
correct in t=
hat I was always doing a one timestep network firing, 
even though there we=
re recurrent connections...yet the GA managed to 
work with that somehow an=
d find a solution to the problem...

Of course, I want to handle the recurr=
ency correctly...the 
suggestions here are very useful and aligned with som=
e thinking I 
had done on the problem...

Now off to coding!!

FYI..when i =
get this working, I will make the code available on the 
web...

Thanks aga=
in!

--Kevin


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@g...> =
wrote:
> I wanted to throw out the other alternative that I myself 
impleme=
nted.  
> 
> Based on what Ken described, a 5 layer network will require be=
ing
> activated in 5 discreet time steps.  But if there is no recurrency,
>=
 then it should be possible to activate it in ONE time step by just
> activ=
ating each of the nodes in the proper order.  That's what I 
did. 
> For a =
given topology, I do a dependency analysis.  From that, I 
figure
> out wha=
t the proper order should be in order to activate individual
> nodes.  If I=
 activate the nodes in that order, then the inputs will
> reach the outputs=
 in a single activation of the network.  This, in
> turn, reduces the numbe=
r of calculations required for an 
activation.
> 
> For recurrent networks,=
 you can do it in much the same way.  
However,
> if node A has an input co=
ming from node B, but node B hasn't been
> calculated, you use an assumed o=
utput of 0 for node B.  On the next
> activation of the network, node B *ha=
s* been calculated.  Let's say
> it's output was X.  So A will use X as the=
 value of the input from 
B.
> 
> Mind you, if you use this technique, you =
will save a great deal on 
CPU
> resources, since you don't have to do near=
ly as many calculations. 
> However, you can't (necessarily) mix the paradi=
gms.  You can't 
develop
> a topology using Ken's activation technique and =
expect it to 
perform
> identically using mine, and vice versa.  It might, =
but it might 
not! 
> So whatever you decide on, stick with it.
> 
> Realis=
tically, how you do it isn't that important.  The network 
will
> learn (or=
 evolve) to solve the problem using whatever method you
> decide upon.  The=
 only advantage of one method over another is in 
how
> much computational =
resources are required either during testing or 
in
> final implementation.=
  My NEAT was written in Perl, which is an
> interpreted language, and so c=
ould benefit from as much 
accelleration
> as I could find.  That's why I o=
pted for the less computationally
> intensive activation method.  If you do=
n't care about CPU resources
> during the firing of the network, then go wi=
th whatever is easiest 
for
> you to code.  :)
> 
> -- John
> 
> On 8/24/05=
, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> > Kevin,
> > 
> > Let me add to =
Charles comments a bit...although Charles does a 
good
> > job giving some =
background, I believe there are some things 
Charles
> > didn't mention you=
 should be aware of.
> > 
> > First, see the question, "How are networks wi=
th arbitrary 
topologies
> > activated?" in the NEAT FAQ located at:
> > 
>=
 > http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html
> > 
> > That question=
 gives some background on your own question.
> > 
> > The short answer is t=
hat every node is activated on every 
timestep
> > from ALL incoming connec=
tions.  Any node that has not yet 
received
> > input it assumed to be outp=
utting a zero.  In other words, time
> > delay does not enter into it at al=
l (I have never actually used 
the
> > time-delay code).  Also, activation =
does not travel all the way 
from
> > inputs to outputs in a single timeste=
p unless there is a direct
> > connection from inputs to outputs.  But acti=
vation traveling over
> > intervening nodes will take extra time to get the=
re.
> > 
> > So what happens is that a node that connects to itself receive=
s 
the
> > activation that itself output on the *previous* timestep.  
Netw=
orks
> > are activated over a series of timesteps.
> > 
> > It is important=
 to note that you should *not* be relaxing a 
network
> > during a control =
task like food gathering.  Charles mentions
> > relaxation but that is only=
 appropriate for classification tasks
> > where the network is trying to de=
cide on a final answer.  See the
> > question, "How do I ensure that a netw=
ork stabilizes before 
taking
> > its output(s) for a classification proble=
m?" in the NEAT FAQ for
> > more info on this.
> > 
> > In a continual cont=
rol task like food gathering (or most tasks 
NEAT
> > is used for) there is=
 always new input coming in and new output
> > coming out, so the network w=
ill never relax, since there is
> > no "final" answer.  The only question t=
hat comes up is how many
> > times (steps) to activate the network per worl=
d tick.  Almost any
> > experiment I've heard of activates once per tick, b=
ut it is 
possible
> > to imagine activating >1 time per tick, which is equ=
ivalent to
> > speeding up the rate of thought.   However, note that more
>=
 > activations also means more CPU time per world tick.
> > 
> > I hope thi=
s help; feel free to ask any other questions.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > 
> > 
>=
 > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Charles Tarun <ctarun@g...> wrote:
> >=
 > Hello Maitrikaruna,
> > > I would like to offer any help I can, and I'm =
sure others will
> > also help,
> > >
> > > I also don't have any training =
on NN either, but I've been 
read a
> > lot about
> > > them. Each implemen=
tation of NEAT handles the firing of the 
node
> > in their
> > > own way, =
as NEAT doesn't define it exactly. My method of 
choice is
> > one of
> > >=
 the SharpNEAT ones, "FastConcurrentNetwork". This network
> > simulates ea=
ch
> > > neuron activating concurrently.
> > >
> > > 1) Assign the values t=
o all input nodes
> > > 2) Activate the network
> > > 3) Relax the network
=
> > > 4) Read the outputs
> > >
> > > Activate network is pass a parameter =
of how many times to run 
for,
> > this is
> > > basically how many steps t=
o run for. Each step uses the signal
> > strength from
> > > the previous.
=
> > >
> > > The Relax network function is very much like the Activate
> > f=
unction, but also
> > > take in a maxAllowedSignalDelta. It runs until the =
signal 
change
> > for each
> > > node is <maxAllowedSignalDelta or the max=
Steps count is 
reached.
> > >
> > > |-------
> > > v |
> > > NODE1-->NODE2=
-->NODE3
> > >
> > > They way I see this working with your diagram is(assum=
ing the
> > links had
> > > enough weight to cause the next to fire):
> > >=

> > > Step 1:
> > > Node1(input) is firing.
> > > node2 get enough signal =
to fire at this time stamp
> > > node3 only getting signal from the previou=
s step when node2 
wasn't
> > firing
> > > does not have enough signal to f=
ire.
> > >
> > > Step2:
> > > Node1(input) is firing.
> > > node2 gets enou=
gh signal to fire from node1's last step, but is
> > not getting
> > > sign=
al from node3.
> > > node3 gets enough signal to fire from node2's last ste=
p and 
fires
> > >
> > > step3:
> > > Node1(input) is firing(As always, inp=
ut nodes don't change)
> > > node2 is getting signal from node1 and node3 n=
ow
> > > node3 is getting signal from node2 last time step, the 
recurrent
=
> > connection
> > > hasn't effected the signal from 2 to 3 yet.
> > >
> > =
> Under such a system it is possible to get oscillation in the
> > signals,=
 that's
> > > why there is a maxSteps on the relax function. The creator of=

> > SharpNEAT is
> > > part of this list as well(Colin D. Green). I hope t=
his will be
> > helpful.
> > >
> > > Chuck Tarun
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> =

ircle representing

sted against four different 
food

s that allow it to "see" in

to

ind
> > > > all the 4 different food bins after about9 or 10 
gens...which =
is

neuro=
n
> > > > firing issue in my code..

 new to NN's...i have no training on 
them

> > > > all, although I d=
o know GA's fairly well (I am CEO of

> > > > firm that u=
ses GA's to analyze genetics data).

e you can help with. the way I setup 
the

rent connections to occur. So 
suppose

k where input node 1 connects to hidden 
node
> > 2,
> > > > which connects=
 to hidden node 3, which connects to back to 
node

ring to proceed in such a scenario? Node 2 can't 
fire

 all its inputs, yet one of its outputs(the one 
to

> > > > 3) aff=
ects what its input will be. Thanks for your help...

 > v |

ks back to itself? Then how is the

like to tackle the tic-tac-
toe
